Homework (due 0205)

Complete these for Monday, February 5. Where appropriate, show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Plot each point and give two other sets of polar coordinates for each point:

    1. \((1,45^\circ)\)

      Other coordinates for this point: \((1,405^\circ)\), \((1,-315^\circ)\), \((-1,225^\circ)\), \((-1,-135^\circ)\), and others

    2. \((3,120^\circ)\)

      Other coordinates for this point: \((3,480^\circ)\), \((3,-240^\circ)\), \((-3,300^\circ)\), \((-3,-60^\circ)\), and others

    3. \((-2,30^\circ)\)

      Other coordinates for this point: \((2,210^\circ)\), \((-2, 390^\circ)\), \((2,-150^\circ)\), \((-2,-330^\circ)\), and others

    4. \((4,\frac{5\pi}{2})\)

      Other coordinates for this point: \((4,90^\circ)\), \((4,-270^\circ)\), \((-4,270^\circ)\), \((-4,-90^\circ)\), and others

    5. \((-1,-120^\circ)\)

      Other coordinates for this point: \((1,60^\circ)\), \((1,-300^\circ)\), \((-1,240^\circ)\), \((-1,600^\circ)\), and others

  2. Considering the polar point \((r,\theta)=(3,\frac{\pi}{3})\), give the three other equivalent polar coordinates for this point such that \(|r|=3\) and \(0<|\theta|<2\pi\).

    The other three coordinates for this point that satisfy the conditions are \(\left(3,-\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)\), \(\left(-3,\frac{4\pi}{3}\right)\), and \(\left(-3,-\frac{2\pi}{3}\right).\)

  3. Convert the following polar coordinates to rectangular coordinates. Give exact coordinates only (no rounded decimals).

    1. \((2,\frac{\pi}{6})\)

      \(\left(2\cos\frac{\pi}{6},2\sin\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=(\sqrt{3},1).\)

    2. \((3,\frac{3\pi}{4})\)

      \(\left(3\cos\frac{3\pi}{4},3\sin\frac{3\pi}{4}\right)=\left(-\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2},\frac{3\sqrt{2}}{2}\right).\)

    3. \((-2,45^\circ)\)

      \(\left(-2\cos 45^\circ,-2\sin 45^\circ\right)=(-\sqrt{2},-\sqrt{2}).\)

    4. \((-1,-\frac{7\pi}{6})\)

      \(\left(-1\cos(-\frac{7\pi}{6}),-1\sin(-\frac{7\pi}{6})\right)=\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2},-\frac{1}{2}\right).\)

  4. Convert the following rectangular coordinates to polar coordinates. Give exact \(r\)-coordinates and give \(\theta\) coordinates rounded to the nearest degree.
    1. \((1,2)\)

      For \(r\): \(1^2+2^2=r^2\), so \(r=\pm\sqrt{5}\). For \(\theta\): we are in the first quadrant and \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{1}\right)\approx 63^\circ\). Thus the desired coordinates are \((\sqrt{5},63^\circ)\).

    2. \((-3,0)\)

      For \(r\): \((-3)^2+0^2=r^2\), so \(r=\pm 3\). For \(\theta\): we are on the left half of the \(x\)-axis, so \(\theta\) could be \(180^\circ\). Thus the desired coordinates are \((3, 180^\circ)\).

    3. \((-3,4)\)

      For \(r\): \((-3)^2+4^2=r^2\), so \(r=\pm 5\). For \(\theta\): we are in the second quadrant and \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{4}{-3}\right)\approx -53^\circ\). To get \(\theta\) in Quadrant II, add \(180^\circ\). Thus the desired coordinates are \((5,127^\circ)\).

    4. \((-2,-5)\)

      For \(r\): \((-2)^2+(-5)^2=r^2\), so \(r=\pm\sqrt{29}\). For \(\theta\): we are in the third quadrant and \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-5}{-2}\right)\approx 68^\circ\). To get \(\theta\) in Quadrant III, add \(180^\circ\). Thus the desired coordinates are \((\sqrt{29},248^\circ)\).

    5. \((2,-5)\)

      For \(r\): \((2)^2+(-5)^2=r^2\), so \(r=\pm\sqrt{29}\). For \(\theta\): we are in the fourth quadrant and \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-5}{2}\right)\approx -68^\circ\). Thus the desired coordinates are \((\sqrt{29},-68^\circ)\).
